commentBody: Yay for Mallory and Zhou! I love that their constructors' notes have a playfulness befitting the puzzle (and, in my experience as Zhou's friend, reflects Zhou's personality). I'm looking forward to meeting them at ACPT!
I enjoyed solving this, but IMHO it was Wednesday difficulty. The theme did not help me solve; rather, it explained answers that were driven by the crosses but didn't seem to match the clues.
¬°AY PAPI! Fun puzzle!
Being Canadian I know little Spanish, so the cross to AYPAPI could have been BOINK, DOINK, ZOINK. If you sound these out loud people look at you funny.

I got the theme easily enough. But because it IS a Thursday, to me it is inexcusable that rebuses were not accepted as alternatives in the crossing squares. It took me forever to suss out which letter(s) were acceptable and otherwise ruined a fun puzzle finagling the app to get the happy music.
Very lively puzzle. Thanks, constructors! And the guest Wordplay columnist seems to know something about crosswords. I'll have the ELOTE with GLEE.
An A+ puzzle. While the theme was fairly easily uncovered, the fresh answers and cluing made this particularly entertaining. And how nice to see a Wordplay column from Will Shortz.

It wasn't a near Wednesday for me!  

I "finished" in about average Thursday time, but then had to spend over four minutes finding mistakes and corrections before it finally clicked.

I tried entering the inflated grades as rebuses (A/B, B/C etc.), but of course that didn't work.  (I still think maybe it should have.)

The Heineken subsidiary was a large time waster, since the vowel (U) necessary for it to cross the Boolean value was a "true" Natick for me.  If only I'd been a beer-loving coder!

It's never as much fun to wrestle with a puzzle you thought you had finished, but I can't blame this one on the constructors.  Now that it's done, I admire the idea and the execution.  Nice work!

This puzzle's trick reminds me of Victor Borge's Inflationary Language ( https://youtu.be/e2lpHhL1uxo ) ... obviously that is numbers instead of grades, but.

Nope.  Two fails in a row.  Feels like I'm losing the grip.

Very clever puzzle, though, I have to say.  I would have been proud to have solved it.

Regarding the weather, the ice in Minnesota is particularly dangerous this year.  I passed a lady coming out of the grocery store tonight who slipped and fell.  Fortunately she was all right, but not everyone has been that lucky.

I would love to see a thaw, but I don't think one is coming.  I don't think one is coming for a long, long time.

Loved the puzzle. Seeing FIFTYCENT immediately brought me back to my high school days, where saying ‚Äúfifty‚Äù was just plain wrong. It had to be ‚Äúfiddy.‚Äù

Turns out it came about from Sharon Osborne, who famously pronounced his name that way at the 2003 MTV Music Awards.

I found this humorous tidbit from an article (Elite Daily):

Basically, 50 Cent said you can refer to him as both "Fifty" and "Fiddy," depending on what type of person you are.

For example, if you call a $100 bill a "$100 bill," you should call him "Fifty." But, if you call a $100 bill a "Benjamin," then you should call him "Fiddy."

If I might offer some unsolicited advice that may have been helpful today and going forward.

Don't consider a rebus until it hits you over the head.  In other words, pretend rebuses do not exist until they have to in order to solve the puzzle.  It may take getting burned a few times before this makes sense.

A trick I gleaned from @DC-- In a puzzle in which you are uncertain what *how* to enter the information, or what format the puzzle will accept, erase one square of which you're entirely certain--1A/1D is always a good bet--and fill it in as the last square. If you don't hear the music, erase it again, go back and change the rebus squares, or whatever, and try again. If that fails, read Wordplay. Like many, I entered the squares in the format [X/Y], and had to go back and change them. *** *** *** Here's an unexpected YouTube find: a piece for VIOLA d'amore and HARP, by the Kurdish (Iraqi) composer/performer Abdullah Jamal Sagrima: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D1wg7cKFijk The viola d'amore differs from the usual, modern viola most notably by having "sympathetic strings": extra strings, which are not played directly, but resonate, in "sympathy" with the strings which are being used. The harpist does not appear in the video--is it because the harp part has been synthesized (unlikely), or because the harpist could not be photographed, for some reason? I'll have to check out more of Mr. Sagrima's work.

Grade puzzle!

Very impressive how Mallory and Zhou came up with answer pairs differing by one letter, with those differing letters being alphabet neighbors.  Not to mention, they only had F, D, C, and B to work with.  Plus, those answers had to fit grid symmetry.

And ‚Ä¶ the answer pairs are both in-the-language phrases -- wow!  Try coming up with some of these ‚Äì I, for one, did with very little success, and thus my bedazzlement with what they did.

I liked seeing ABCS as an answer in a grid about school grades.  Also liked seeing AYES, a grade-inflation of ‚Äúbyes‚Äù, echoing the theme. Plus, it was lovely to see ROSA again, who we saw on Monday, also clued by playing on ‚ÄúParks‚Äù.

Congratulations, Mallory, on your NYT debut, and Zhou on your fourth, and thank you both for a fun solve with wow overtones!

The clue for ELOTE was used correctly in the puzzle, but there's a distinction between ELOTE and MAIZ. 

Ma√≠z, a universally accepted term among Spanish-speaking countries, denotes corn in its most generic sense. Meanwhile, choclo, used mostly in South America, and elote, predominantly used in Central America, both commonly represent an ear of sweet corn. (Or the kernels scraped from the cob).

If you're going to eat corn tortillas, they'll be tortillas de ma√≠z, but that other stuff will be elote on the cob or in creamed soup in Mexico.

The reason why many tried to enter rebuses (aside from it being a Thursday) is that not only did it make the answers work (across and down), but also, it showed a progressive series (top to bottom) of ‚Äúgrade inflations‚Äù: F/D, D/C, C/B, B/A. Had they not been in order that way, the rebuses wouldn‚Äôt have seemed so correct.

For those who were expecting a rebus, I will expand on my earlier comments. I hear what you are saying but in the future I think these hints will help:

1) Double rebuses are rare to begin with, and would even be more rarely seen with only one letter in both directions

2) if a double rebus is used, the revealer will will indicate some justification for the rebus, and indicate that it applies to a location or cell in the grid, not just across entries

3) Think about the implication of the revealer. GRADE INFLATION means that the grade was CHANGED from a lower to higher grade‚Äînot that both grades exist together or side by side.

4) In general, assume that a rebus isn‚Äôt used if it isn‚Äôt necessary, and in this case it isn‚Äôt. The grade inflation is implied by the change in the letter for the across, and the downs are perfect as they are.

5) Lastly, I say this about any double rebus‚Äîif you think it‚Äôs one, only put in one direction to save yourself the headache of making sure the order or formatting is correct. It‚Äôs usually pretty standard but I hear enough complaints and have never had a problem doing this. This may or may not have helped today if you happened to put the incorrect across letter in and not the downs.

Again, you are not stupid or thoughtless for thinking there might be‚Äîafter all, a lot of smart people came to the same conclusion‚Äîbut in my experience the above criteria would be necessary for a rebus and they weren‚Äôt met in this case, so maybe this will help.

@Marlene
1. Although the term 'naticks' originated with a crossing of two proper nouns, it's generally agreed that it applies to other categories of words.
2. 'Yenta' /is/ a proper name in Yiddish. It has become an eponym, acting as a model for every gossipy old woman but it began as and remains a proper name.
3. Its use in Fiddler is based on this secondary meaning. To refer to an era before any of our times, it's as if a 40s musical had a gossipy character named Hedda.

@Domenic et al. I think the real gist of Natickhood, is not whether the two words are proper nouns, but 1) how obscure the two entries are, and 2) how many letters would possibly fit in the crossing. Consider YE_TAS/_AST: now, if you recognize that YE_TAS is a Yiddish word (which you might not), the most likely letters before the T would be L, N, R, or V. But _AST is an "American" name, from when the nation was waspier: I know there are persons with the surname "Last," and can imagine Rasts and Vasts, but the most likely one is N-Nast. FWIW, I always have to think whether the cartoonist is "Nast" or "Nash." https://www.yelp.com/search?find_desc=Neighborhoods&find_loc=Natick%2C+MA+01760
